docs.lead_paragraph: True or false? Strokes happen only to older people. Strokes occur without warning. There is nothing you can do to prevent a stroke. Few who survive a stroke are ever normal again. ALL the above statements are, as you may have guessed, false. The very myths that surround stroke - the nation's third leading cause of death - contribute to its disabling of so many thousands of Americans annually. The truth is that stroke can occur at any age, though it is far more common after age 60; that many, perhaps most, strokes are preventable and that to be most effective prevention should start while you are young.

headline.main: STROKE, A MAIN CAUSE OF DEATH, IS SURROUNDED WITH MYTHS

docs.snippet: True or false?  Strokes happen only to older people.  Strokes occur without warning.  There is nothing you can do to prevent a stroke.  Few who survive a stroke are ever normal again.   ALL the above statements are, as you may have guessed, false....

docs.lead_paragraph: Though for centuries menstruating women were accused of malingering when they complained of pain and other discomforts, recent evidence has shown that menstrual symptoms have a physiological basis. Hormone-like substances called prostaglandins, which are often released in large amounts in the uterus when menstruation begins, have been singled out as the likely cause.
